com.localytics.android

Class Localytics

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.localytics.android.Localytics

  • public class Localytics
extends java.lang.Object
    All calls to the Localytics library go through this singleton.

      • integrate

        public static void integrate(@NonNull
                             android.content.Context context)
        Integrates Localytics and initializes the Handlers.
        Parameters:
        context - The context used to access resources on behalf of the app. Cannot be null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if context is an Activity context or null, if ll_app_key in localytics.xml is null or empty, or if PushReceiver is declared in AndroidManifest.xml but PushTrackingActivity isn't declared

      • autoIntegrate

                                 android.app.Application application)
        Integrates Localytics.
        Parameters:
        application - The app's application object. Cannot be null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if application is null, or if ll_app_key in localytics.xml is null or empty.

      • upload

        public static void upload()
        Initiates an upload of all Localytics data. This should be done early in the process life in order to guarantee as much time as possible for slow connections to complete. It is necessary to do this even if the user has opted out because this is how the opt out is transported to the webservice.

      • pauseDataUploading

        public static void pauseDataUploading(boolean pause)
        Halt the uploading of Analytics and Profiles data to the Localytics servers. Re-enabling the upload of data will cause an immediate upload.
        Parameters:
        pause - if set to true, all data uploading will be halted. If false, data uploading will resume as normal.

      • setOptedOut

        public static void setOptedOut(boolean newOptOut)
        Sets the Localytics opt-out state for this application. This call is not necessary and is provided for people who wish to allow their users the ability to opt out of data collection. It can be called at any time. Passing true causes all further data collection to stop, and an opt-out event to be sent to the server so the user's data is removed from the charts.
        There are very serious implications to the quality of your data when providing an opt out option. For example, users who have opted out will appear as never returning, causing your new/returning chart to skew.
        If two instances of the same application are running, and one is opted in and the second opts out, the first will also become opted out, and neither will collect any more data.
        If a session was started while the app was opted out, the session open event has already been lost. For this reason, all sessions started while opted out will not collect data even after the user opts back in or else it taints the comparisons of session lengths and other metrics.
        Parameters:
        newOptOut - True if the user should be be opted out, halting further data collection
        See Also:
        isOptedOut()

      • setPrivacyOptedOut

        public static void setPrivacyOptedOut(boolean privacyOptedOut)
        Sets the Localytics opt-out state for this application. This call is not necessary and is provided for people who wish to allow their users the ability to opt out of data collection. It can be called at any time. Passing true causes all further data collection to stop, and an opt-out event to be sent to the server so the user's data is removed from the charts.
        Additionally, a profile attribute will be set causing a deletion of data request to be made for Localytics in line with the GDPR standard. There are very serious implications to the quality of your data when providing an opt out option. For example, users who have opted out will appear as never returning, causing your new/returning chart to skew.
        As a side effect of protecting a user's data, the SDK will internally ensure that ADID's are no longer appended to the url's of In-App and Inbox call to action links.
        Parameters:
        privacyOptedOut - True if the user should be privacy opted out and have all his Localytics data deleted.
        See Also:
        setOptedOut(boolean), isPrivacyOptedOut()

      • isOptedOut

        public static boolean isOptedOut()
        Get the opted in/out state.
        Returns:
        True if opted out; false otherwise.
        See Also:
        setOptedOut(boolean)

      • isPrivacyOptedOut

        Get the privacy opted in/out state.
        Returns:
        True if privacy opted out; false otherwise.
        See Also:
        setPrivacyOptedOut(boolean)

      • openSession

        public static void openSession()
        Opens the Localytics session. The session should be opened before tagEvent(String), tagEvent(String, java.util.Map), tagEvent(String, java.util.Map), or tagScreen(String) are called.

        If a new session is opened shortly--within a few seconds--after an earlier session is closed, Localytics will reconnect to the previous session (effectively causing the previous close to be ignored). This ensures that as a user moves from Activity to Activity in an app, that is considered a single session. When a session is reconnected, the customDimensions for the initial open are kept and dimensions for the second open are ignored.

        If for any reason open is called more than once without an intervening call to closeSession(), subsequent calls to open will be ignored.

      • closeSession

        public static void closeSession()
        Closes the Localytics session. Once a session has been opened via openSession(), close the session when data collection is complete.

        If close is called without open having ever been called, the close has no effect. Similarly, once a session is closed, subsequent calls to close will be ignored.

      • tagEvent

        public static void tagEvent(java.lang.String eventName)
        Behaves identically to calling tagEvent(eventName, null, 0).
        Parameters:
        eventName - The name of the event which occurred. Cannot be null or empty string.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if eventName is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if eventName is empty.
        See Also:
        tagEvent(String, java.util.Map, long)

      • tagEvent

        public static void tagEvent(java.lang.String eventName,
                            java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> attributes)
        Behaves identically to calling tagEvent(eventName, attributes, 0).
        Parameters:
        eventName - The name of the event which occurred. Cannot be null or empty string.
        attributes - The collection of attributes for this particular event. If this parameter is null or empty, then calling this method has the same effect as calling tagEvent(String). This parameter may not contain null or empty keys or values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if eventName is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if eventName is empty.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if attributes contains null keys, empty keys, null values, or empty values.
        See Also:
        tagEvent(String, java.util.Map, long)

      • tagEvent

        public static void tagEvent(java.lang.String eventName,
                            java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> attributes,
                            long customerValueIncrease)

        Within the currently open session, tags that event occurred (with optionally included attributes).

        Attributes: Additional key/value pairs with data related to an event. For example, let's say your app displays a dialog with two buttons: OK and Cancel. When the user clicks on one of the buttons, the event might be "button clicked." The attribute key might be "button_label" and the value would either be "OK" or "Cancel" depending on which button was clicked.

        Best Practices
        • DO NOT use events, attributes, or dimensions to record personally identifiable information.
        • The best way to use events is to create all the event strings as predefined constants and only use those. This is more efficient and removes the risk of collecting personal information.
        • Do not tag events inside loops or any other place which gets called frequently. This can cause a lot of data to be stored and uploaded.
        Parameters:
        eventName - The name of the event which occurred. Cannot be null or empty string.
        attributes - The collection of attributes for this particular event. If this parameter is null or empty, then no attributes are recorded and the behavior with respect to attributes is like simply calling tagEvent(String). This parameter may not contain null or empty keys or values.
        customerValueIncrease - Added to customer lifetime value. Try to use lowest possible unit, such as cents for US currency.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if eventName is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if eventName is empty.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if attributes contains null keys, empty keys, null values, or empty values.

      • tagPurchased

        public static void tagPurchased(@Nullable
                                java.lang.String itemName,
                                @Nullable
                                java.lang.String itemId,
                                @Nullable
                                java.lang.String itemType,
                                @Nullable
                                java.lang.Long itemPrice,
                                @Nullable
                                java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> attributes)
        A standard event to tag a single item purchase event (after the action has occurred)
        Parameters:
        itemName - The name of the item purchased (optional, can be null)
        itemId - A unique identifier of the item being purchased, such as a SKU (optional, can be null)
        itemType - The type of item (optional, can be null)
        itemPrice - The price of the item (optional, can be null). Will be added to customer lifetime value. Try to use lowest possible unit, such as cents for US currency.
        attributes - Any additional attributes to attach to this event (optional, can be null)

      • tagScreen

        public static void tagScreen(java.lang.String screen)
        Note: This implementation will perform duplicate suppression on two identical screen events that occur in a row within a single session. For example, in the set of screens {"Screen 1", "Screen 1"} the second screen would be suppressed. However in the set {"Screen 1", "Screen 2", "Screen 1"}, no duplicate suppression would occur.
        Parameters:
        screen - Name of the screen that was entered. Cannot be null or the empty string.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if screen is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if screen is empty.

      • setCustomDimension

        public static void setCustomDimension(int dimension,
                                      java.lang.String value)
        Sets the value of a custom dimension. Custom dimensions are dimensions which contain user defined data unlike the predefined dimensions such as carrier, model, and country. Once a value for a custom dimension is set, the device it was set on will continue to upload that value until the value is changed. To clear a value pass null as the value. The proper use of custom dimensions involves defining a dimension with less than ten distinct possible values and assigning it to one of the four available custom dimensions. Once assigned this definition should never be changed without changing the App Key otherwise old installs of the application will pollute new data.
        Parameters:
        dimension - A dimension between 0 and 9.
        value - The value to set for the given dimension.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if dimension is not between 0 and 9.
        See Also:
        getCustomDimension(int)

      • getCustomDimension

        public static java.lang.String getCustomDimension(int dimension)
        Get the current value for a given dimension.
        Parameters:
        dimension - A dimension between 0 and 9.
        Returns:
        The current value for the given dimension.
        See Also:
        setCustomDimension(int, String)

                                        AnalyticsListener listener)

        • AnalyticsListener.localyticsSessionDidOpen(boolean, boolean, boolean)
        • AnalyticsListener.localyticsSessionWillClose()
        Parameters:
        listener - The object that will receive the callbacks. Pass in null to remove an existing listener.

      • setInAppMessageDisplayActivity

        public static void setInAppMessageDisplayActivity(android.app.Activity activity)
        Attach the current foreground activity Localytics. The fragment manager associated with each activity is needed for showing the dialog fragment which hosts the marketing dialog. This method gets the fragment manager from the input activity and attaches it with the marketing handler which controls the marketing trigger.
        Parameters:
        activity - The foreground activity, must not be null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if activity is null.
        See Also:
        clearInAppMessageDisplayActivity()

        Opposite from the setInAppMessageDisplayActivity, this method detaches any fragment manager from Localytics.
        See Also:
        setInAppMessageDisplayActivity(android.app.Activity)

      • triggerInAppMessage

        public static void triggerInAppMessage(java.lang.String triggerName)
        Trigger an in-app message
        Parameters:
        triggerName - The name of the in-app message trigger

      • triggerInAppMessagesForSessionStart

        public static void triggerInAppMessagesForSessionStart()
        Trigger campaigns as if a Session Start event had just occurred.

        This is useful for integrations that want to delay presentation of startup campaigns due to some startup state, such as a splash screen. In order to delay the triggering, implement MessagingListenerV2 and respond appropriately to MessagingListenerV2.localyticsShouldDelaySessionStartInAppMessages(). Finally, once the start up state has cleared, call this method to trigger in-app campaigns as if a session had just been started.

      • triggerInAppMessage

        public static void triggerInAppMessage(java.lang.String triggerName,

      • dismissCurrentInAppMessage

        public static void dismissCurrentInAppMessage()
        If an in-app message is currently displayed, dismiss it. Is a no-op otherwise.

      • registerPush

        public static void registerPush()
        Register app to receive push notifications from Localytics.
        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - if using GCM and no value is filled out for sender_id in the localytics.xml
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if neither com.google.android.gms:play-services-gcm or com.google.firebase:firebase-messaging is included in the app.

      • getPushRegistrationId

        public static java.lang.String getPushRegistrationId()
        Returns:
        The push registration Id once the app has registered with GCM.

      • setPushRegistrationId

        public static void setPushRegistrationId(java.lang.String registrationId)
        Set the push registration Id which was registered with GCM
        Parameters:
        registrationId - The GCM registration Id

      • setNotificationsDisabled

        @Deprecated
public static void setNotificationsDisabled(boolean disable)
        Deprecated. This is deprecated in SDK 5.1 so that the standard dimension "notifications enabled" can be directly tied to the OS setting. We recommend using a custom dimension to continue supporting any app-level notification settings.
        Enable or disable the app from receiving push notifications from Localytics. Should be called only after registerPush() has been called. This is typically used for app-level notification settings, since for Android 4.4+ this is populated with the OS-level settings from the support library.
        Parameters:
        disable - Boolean flag to enable or disable push notifications. Note that true value disables push while a false value enables it.
        See Also:
        areNotificationsDisabled()

      • areNotificationsDisabled

        @Deprecated
public static boolean areNotificationsDisabled()
        Deprecated. @see #setNotificationsDisabled(boolean)
        Get the push disabled/enabled state. This is the OS-level settings for Android 4.4+ unless it has been set with setNotificationsDisabled(boolean).
        Returns:
        Boolean indicating whether Localytics push notifications have been disabled.

      • handlePushNotificationOpened

        Handle opening a Localytics push notification.
        Parameters:
        intent - The Intent of the push notification.

      • handleFirebaseMessage

        public static boolean handleFirebaseMessage(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> messageData)
        Conditionally handles the display of a Firebase remote notification if the message data is determined to be a Localytics message. Will return true if the message was handled, and false otherwise. A return of false indicates a non-Localytics message that should be handled by the calling application.
        Parameters:
        messageData - The data map derived from com.google.firebase.messaging.RemoteMessage.getData()
        Returns:
        true if the message was handled as a Localytics push message, false otherwise

      • tagPushReceivedEvent

        public static void tagPushReceivedEvent(android.os.Bundle data)
        Handle tagging the Localytics Push Received event. Use this method if you use your own BroadcastReceiver or Service (and not the Localytics GcmReceiver. Pass the Intent extras delivered to BroadcastReceiver.onReceive(Context, Intent) or Bundle delivered to GcmListenerService.onMessageReceived(String, Bundle) to this method to tag the 'Localytics Push Received' event.
        Parameters:
        data - The Bundle of the push notification.

      • tagPushReceivedEvent

        public static void tagPushReceivedEvent(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> data)
        Handle tagging the Localytics Push Received event. Use this method if you use your own FirebaseMessagingService (and not the Localytics FirebaseService or handleFirebaseMessage(Map) method). Pass the RemoteMessage.getData() delivered to FirebaseMessagingService.onMessageReceived(com.google.firebase.messaging.RemoteMessage) to this method to tag the 'Localytics Push Received' event.
        Parameters:
        data - The data of the push notification retrieved by calling RemoteMessage.getData().

      • displayPushNotification

        Handle displaying a Localytics push notification.
        Parameters:
        data - The Bundle of the push notification.
        Returns:
        true if the message was handled as a Localytics push message, false otherwise

      • handleTestMode

        public static void handleTestMode(android.content.Intent intent)
        Handle the intent for push test mode. User can define the correct intent filter in the Manifest.xml file so when they got the mail from Localytics they can enable the marketing test mode or test the marketing push immediately.
        Parameters:
        intent - The same intent object from activity's getIntent method. The intent contains params for push test mode. Cannot be null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if intent is null.

      • setTestModeEnabled

        public static void setTestModeEnabled(boolean enabled)
        Enable/Disable the test mode with the given flag. If the user is not in the test mode, all marketing-message dialogs will not show once and the information to show the dialog will be deleted after the dialog is closed. In test mode, the information will never be deleted so the same marketing-message dialog will always show under the right condition.
        Parameters:
        enabled - Flag to indicate whether to enable the test mode or not.
        See Also:
        isTestModeEnabled()

      • isTestModeEnabled

        public static boolean isTestModeEnabled()
        Determine whether the test mode is enabled.
        Returns:
        true if the test mode is enabled, otherwise false.
        See Also:
        setTestModeEnabled(boolean)

      • setMessagingListener

        public static void setMessagingListener(@Nullable
                                        MessagingListenerV2 listener)
        Add a listener that will be notified of certain messaging callbacks:
        • MessagingListenerV2.localyticsDidDisplayInAppMessage()
        • MessagingListenerV2.localyticsWillDismissInAppMessage()
        • MessagingListenerV2.localyticsDidDismissInAppMessage()
        • MessagingListenerV2.localyticsShouldShowInAppMessage(InAppCampaign)}
        • MessagingListenerV2.localyticsShouldDelaySessionStartInAppMessages()}
        • MessagingListenerV2.localyticsWillDisplayInAppMessage(InAppCampaign, InAppConfiguration)
        Note, all methods invoked by this interface will be invoked on the main thread. As a result, please ensure that no calls perform any blocking operations.
        Parameters:
        listener - The object that will receive the callbacks. Pass in null to remove an existing listener.

      • setCallToActionListener

        public static void setCallToActionListener(@Nullable
                                           CallToActionListener listener)
        Add a listener that will be notified of certain callbacks:
        • CallToActionListener.localyticsShouldDeeplink(String, Campaign)
        • CallToActionListener.localyticsDidOptOut(boolean, Campaign)
        • CallToActionListener.localyticsDidPrivacyOptOut(boolean, Campaign)
        Note, all methods invoked by this interface will be invoked on the main thread. As a result, please ensure that no calls perform any blocking operations.
        Parameters:
        listener - The object that will receive the callbacks. Pass in null to remove an existing listener.

      • setInboxCampaignRead

        public static void setInboxCampaignRead(InboxCampaign campaign,
                                        boolean read)
        Set an inbox campaign as read. Read state can be used to display opened inbox campaigns campaigns differently (e.g. an unread indicator).
        Parameters:
        campaign - the campaign object of the Inbox campaign.
        read - true to mark the campaign as read, false to mark it as unread
        See Also:
        InboxCampaign.isRead(), InboxListAdapter

      • deleteInboxCampaign

        public static void deleteInboxCampaign(InboxCampaign campaign)
        Set an inbox campaign as deleted. Deleted Inbox items will no longer be returned in calls to getDisplayableInboxCampaigns or getAllInboxCampaigns and will be removed from UIs.
        Parameters:
        campaign - the campaign object of the Inbox campaign.
        See Also:
        InboxListAdapter

        public static void setCustomerIdWithPrivacyOptedOut(@Nullable
                                                    java.lang.String customerId,
                                                    boolean optedOut)
        Convenience method to set a customer's id. This method will additionally set the privacy opt out state for the user, and will ensure there can be no data leakage for a customer opting out of data collection.
        Parameters:
        customerId - Customer's id.
        optedOut - True if the user should be privacy opted out and have all his Localytics data deleted.

      • onActivityResume

        public static void onActivityResume(@NonNull
                                    android.app.Activity activity)

        Parameters:

      • setOptions

        public static void setOptions(@NonNull
                              java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> options)
        Customize the behavior of the SDK by setting custom values for various options. In each entry, the key specifies the option to modify, and the value specifies what value to set the option to. Options can be restored to default by passing in a value of null, or an empty string for values with type String.
        Parameters:
        options - The map of options and values to modify

      • setOption

        public static void setOption(@NonNull
                             java.lang.String key,
                             @Nullable
                             java.lang.Object value)
        Customize the behavior of the SDK by setting a custom value for an option. The key specifies the option to modify, and the value specifies what value to set the option to. An option can be restored to default by passing in a value of null, or an empty string for values with type String.
        Parameters:
        key - The key of the option
        value - The value of the option or null to restore the default

      • redirectLogsToDisk

        public static void redirectLogsToDisk(boolean writeExternally,
                                      @NonNull
                                      android.content.Context context)
        No production builds should call this method.
        Enable/Disable log rerouting to a file on disk. Calling this method will allow logs to be copied later. The method allows two options:
        • writeExternally set to false will write the logs to files/console.log within the app's directory.
        • writeExternally set to true will write the logs to console.log in the app's external storage directory. This option requires requesting WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE permissions from the user.
        Parameters:
        writeExternally - a boolean value to indicate where to write the logs.
        context - The Application's Context object.

      • isLoggingEnabled

        Check whether the logging is enabled or disabled.
        Returns:
        true if the logging is enabled, otherwise false.
        See Also:
        setLoggingEnabled(boolean)
